name: Sambar
history: Sambar is a staple in South Indian cuisine, believed to have originated in the Tamil Nadu region. It's a lentil-based vegetable stew or chowder, flavored with tamarind and a special blend of spices and herbs, known as sambar powder.
description: Sambar is a flavorful and nutritious South Indian dish made with lentils, a variety of vegetables like carrots, potatoes, eggplant, drumsticks, and pumpkin, tamarind, and a unique blend of spices. It's commonly served with rice, dosa, idli, or vada, and is cherished for its tangy and savory taste.

equipment.name: pot or pressure cooker
equipment.description: For cooking the lentils and vegetables.

instructions.title: Cook the Lentils
instructions.description: Rinse the toor dal thoroughly. Cook it in a pot or pressure cooker with enough water until soft and mushy.

instructions.title: Prepare the Vegetables
instructions.description: Chop the vegetables into bite-sized pieces. Add them to the cooked dal along with tamarind paste, sambar powder, turmeric, and salt. Cook until the vegetables are tender.

instructions.title: Temper the Spices
instructions.description: In a pan, heat oil. Add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, curry leaves, and asafetida. SautÃ© until the mustard seeds start to splutter.

instructions.title: Combine and Simmer
instructions.description: Add the tempering to the cooked dal and vegetable mixture. Simmer for a few minutes.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the sambar hot with rice, dosa, idli, or vada.

tips: Adjust the consistency of the sambar by adding more or less water.
The flavor of sambar depends largely on the sambar powder used, so choose a good quality one.
variations: Include different vegetables like okra, beans, or tomatoes for variation.
Add a spoonful of jaggery or sugar for a hint of sweetness.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2-3 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on the stove or in a microwave until hot.

presentationTips: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves for added flavor and color.
Serve in a traditional Indian serving bowl for an authentic presentation.
